Looks like you and I arrived at the same conclusion
Lol, yah down to the step number

Actually rejecting the capability wouldn't close the sync iterator, would it? That's the problem today, the rejection flows into the promise capability, and into the consumer of the async iterator, which then quarantines the async iterator
It should, given a `throw` will close via the `IfAbruptRejectPromise`, which just calls `capability.[[Reject]]`
content.formatted_body: It should, given a throw will close via the IfAbruptRejectPromise, which just calls capability.[[Reject]]

content.body: I don't see it

I don't see anything that will close the `syncIterator` if the `promiseCapability` is rejected. For that matter, the `syncIterator` is not given to `AsyncFromSyncIteratorContinuation`, so it wouldn't have a way to do it.
content.formatted_body: I don't see anything that will close the syncIterator if the promiseCapability is rejected. For that matter, the syncIterator is not given to AsyncFromSyncIteratorContinuation, so it wouldn't have a way to do it.

content.body: it'd have to be plumbed through as an optional 3rd argument in the case of `next`, as `return` and `throw` already close the `syncIterator` by definition
content.formatted_body: it'd have to be plumbed through as an optional 3rd argument in the case of next, as return and throw already close the syncIterator by definition

Step 6.a gets the `sync.next()` value
it gets the result, aka `{value: Promise, done: boolean}`

content.body: But we get the `value`
In https://tc39.es/ecma262/#sec-asyncfromsynciteratorcontinuation
The promise itself is received as a normal completion, but it's either rejected or will reject
and from what I understand `AsyncFromSyncIteratorContinuation` grabs `done` and `value` from the result, awaits the `value` and resolves a promise with `{done, value: awaitedValue}`
content.formatted_body: and from what I understand AsyncFromSyncIteratorContinuation grabs done and value from the result, awaits the value and resolves a promise with {done, value: awaitedValue}

content.body: If we pass `capibility.[[Reject]]` to `PerformPromiseThen`, then it'll eventually call that reject
content.formatted_body: If we pass capibility.[[Reject]] to PerformPromiseThen, then it'll eventually call that reject

content.body: if the await throws, it rejects the promise, but the `syncIterator` is not touched anymore
content.formatted_body: if the await throws, it rejects the promise, but the syncIterator is not touched anymore

content.body: There's a close step
right but rejecting the promise does nothing besides giving a rejected promise to the async iterator consumer
one fix to this would be to add a handler to `valueWrapper` which closes the iterator, though that seems kinda silly
content.formatted_body: one fix to this would be to add a handler to valueWrapper which closes the iterator, though that seems kinda silly

content.body: aye that's what I'm arguing we need to do
another fix is to have for-await-of explicitly coordinate with the wrapper, which seems kinda painful
why is it silly ?
what we have right now is basically the wrapper not cleaning up after itself
because we'd be unwrapping the promise twice
it missed a `try-catch` when `await`ing the value
content.formatted_body: it missed a try-catch when awaiting the value

content.body: how so, the 3rd argument in step 10 does nothing right now, instead it needs to cleanup and passthrough the error
